page.title: 02LANDSCAPE OF MORFA BYCHAN
page.content: The dominant feature is the 858ft high hill,Moel-y-Gest,from which the ground falls steeply to the flat land,once sea bed,in the south where the village is.Formed of Cambrian rock,the hill sides have pockets of thin,stony soil. A hill fort,hut circles,a cromlech, stone boundary walls and old stone quarry workings show the effects of the past on the hill.Water drains into five streams.There is a small lake at Garreg Wen and an interesting area to the west,Llyn (lake) Ystymllyn,once a sea inlet,then a marsh,now largely drained and cultivated.The estuary of the River Glaslyn to the east has an ever-changing course,causing erosion in places.
